Metadata.title: Free Color Personality Test | 24bitColors
Metadata.description: Discover your true color from 16.77 million colors. Just choose the colors that feel right to you. No registration required, takes less than 3 minutes.

Home.heroDescription:
The color lying deep within your subconscious.
Based on your answers to 20 questions,
we statistically identify the color you prefer most
from 16.77 million possibilities.
Home.conceptBody:
From a sea of 16.77 million colors,
embark on a journey to find your true color.
This is a quiet museum where only you and colors exist.
Home.logicBody:
Our unique algorithm based on color psychology and information engineering
analyzes your potential color preferences.
It learns your preference trends from your selection history
and converges to the optimal solution from 16.77 million colors,
rather than simple random extraction.

About.title: About 24bitColors
About.heroSubtitle: For universal beauty and intellectual curiosity.
About.conceptBody1:
Our world is overflowing with infinite colors.
There are approximately 16.77 million "24bit colors" that a digital screen can represent.
Within that vast number, there is always a "perfect color" for you,
unaffected by the evaluations of others or trends.
About.conceptBody2:
24bitColors is a place to find your true color
relying on your sensibilities from such a sea of colors.
We provide a quiet space without noise to face your intuition.
About.scienceBody1:
We reinterpret the subjective sense of "beauty" through the power of science.
By adopting "OKLCH", the color space closest to human perceptual characteristics,
we have accurately quantified the "brightness" and "vividness" felt by people.
About.scienceBody2:
Your feelings of "liking" are mathematically interpreted
by advanced statistical algorithms and converge to the optimal solution from 16.77 million colors.
That is the moment when art and science merge.
About.visionBody1:
The purpose of this project goes beyond just a diagnostic tool.
We aim to accumulate data on "colors" chosen by people around the world
and build a database of human color preferences.
About.visionBody2:
What do people find beautiful across borders and language barriers?
Through the common language of "color",
we visualize the diversity and universality of human sensibilities.
That is the future we envision.

DiagnosisLogic.title: Behind the Logic
DiagnosisLogic.description: Explanation of the 24bitColors diagnostic algorithm. About the mechanism of identifying personal color sense using OKLCH color space close to human perception and statistical approach.
DiagnosisLogic.intro:
Supporting the diagnostic accuracy of 24bitColors,
About logic based on science and statistics.
DiagnosisLogic.bodyTransparency: Diagnoses by AI or algorithms tend to be opaque black boxes where "why that result was obtained" is unclear. We value satisfaction and transparency regarding results by visualizing the logical structure of colors and optimizing the process by which only your color is derived.
DiagnosisLogic.bodyColorSpace: The RGB color space used in general Web design actually deviates from human senses. 24bitColors adopts "OKLCH", the latest color space closest to human perceptual characteristics. This makes it possible to quantify "brightness" and "vividness" as felt by the senses and analyze even delicate nuances that could not be captured by conventional diagnosis.
DiagnosisLogic.bodyAdaptive: We don't just ask predetermined questions in order. The system analyzes your answers in real time and instantly calculates "which colors to compare next to narrow down preferences most". Using hundreds of "observation points" placed in the 16.77 million color space, we statistically analyze your preference trends and adaptively approach the optimal color region with each selection.
DiagnosisLogic.bodyEvolution: This algorithm is not the final form. We adjust logic daily in response to feedback from users such as "I want to choose more achromatic colors" or "Questions are too similar". Your diagnosis results and impressions directly lead to accuracy improvement for someone else. Our exploration of color continues to evolve with you.

LogicOklch.title: What is OKLCH?
LogicOklch.description: Why OKLCH instead of HSL or RGB? Scientific basis for 'correct color diagnosis' brought by the latest color space faithful to human perception.
LogicOklch.heading:
THE SCIENCE OF
OKLCH & OKLAB
LogicOklch.introLarge: Putting the human 'eye' directly into a formula.
LogicOklch.introSmall:
At the heart of 24bitColors are the latest color spaces born in 2020: 'OKLCH' and 'OKLAB'.
This is not just a new color picker. It is a revolutionary event where computers can finally feel color in the same way as humans.
LogicOklch.sec1Body1: The 'HSL color space' traditionally used in Web design had a fatal flaw. That is, 'Numerical brightness does not match perceived brightness.'
LogicOklch.sec1Body2: Look at the diagram below. HSL formulas claim that dark blue and bright yellow have the same '50% Lightness'. But clearly, yellow looks dazzling to your eyes, right?
LogicOklch.sec1Body3: 'The numbers are correct, but the design looks mismatched.' OKLCH solved this long-standing worry of designers with a biological approach. By incorporating the stimuli received by the retina into the formula, blue and yellow can now be managed with 'correct brightness' as felt by humans.
LogicOklch.graphLabel: ▲ Difference in perceived brightness at HSL 'Lightness 50%'.
LogicOklch.sec2Body1: On this site, we use the terms 'OKLCH' and 'OKLAB' depending on the situation, but they are actually different representations of the exact same color space. It is just like the difference between expressing a location on a map by 'latitude and longitude' or 'how many kilometers northeast from here'.
LogicOklch.oklabDesc: Like mathematical XY coordinates. Ideal for calculating 'color distance'. In this diagnosis, OKLAB is active behind the scenes for judging achromatic colors (gray) and calculating closeness between colors.
LogicOklch.oklchDesc: Like a compass and distance. Suitable for human intuitive operations like 'more vivid' or 'more red'. We use this for displaying diagnosis results and analyzing your preferences on the surface.
LogicOklch.sec2Body2: 24bitColors is characterized by balancing calculation 'accuracy' and human 'intuition' by freely moving between these two. especially in handling achromatic colors (black and white), OKLAB is essential for expressing beautiful grays because it can define perfect nothingness as 'a=0, b=0'.
LogicOklch.sec3Body1: Web design until now has been trapped inside the color cage called 'sRGB'. sRGB is a standard created based on CRT monitors over 20 years ago, and cannot express even half of the vivid colors in the real world.
LogicOklch.sec3Body2: However, OKLCH has no theoretical 'upper limit of saturation'. Although many smartphones and PC monitors can still only output the sRGB range, the latest iPhones and MacBooks (Display P3 compatible) are already starting to display colors outside of it.
LogicOklch.sec3Body3: By building the algorithm with OKLCH, we have secured 'Future-Proofivity' that can fully utilize the performance of any high-performance display that appears in the future. The color you chose today should shine more vividly and beautifully when viewed on a display 10 years from now.

LogicAlgorithm.title: Algorithm Mechanism
LogicAlgorithm.description: Unique dialogue engine using Bayesian inference and information theory. The full picture of the statistical process to identify your preference from 16.77 million colors.
LogicAlgorithm.heading:
ADAPTIVE
ALGORITHM
LogicAlgorithm.introSmall:
This diagnosis is not just a personality test or fortune telling.
It is an interactive search engine that applies probability statistics and information theory to keep calculating the shortest route to the 'ideal color' in your brain.
LogicAlgorithm.sec1Title: '263 Buoys' Floating in the Sea of 16.77 Million Colors
LogicAlgorithm.sec1Body1: PC and smartphone screens can theoretically display 16.77 million colors. Finding the one single color you are looking for from this vast sea of colors is like looking for a ring dropped in the Pacific Ocean. You won't find it by searching blindly.
LogicAlgorithm.sec1Body2: So, this system placed 263 'observation points (candidate colors)' at equal intervals on the entire map called color space. These are like GPS satellites or buoys floating in the sea.
LogicAlgorithm.sec1Body3: Importantly, these 263 colors are not 'answer candidates (choices)'. They are merely sensors to sense 'around where' your preference lies. Since the final diagnosis result is calculated by mathematically interpolating (filling) between these points, even colors located where there are no buoys can be identified with near-infinite smoothness.
LogicAlgorithm.noteBody: Theoretically, more points are placed (496), but as a result of strictly excluding 'areas where colors are crushed' that are visible to the human eye but cannot be reproduced on general monitors (sRGB), these 263 elites survived. If display performance improves around the world in the future, the number of these guideposts is designed to increase automatically.
LogicAlgorithm.sec2Body1: The moment diagnosis begins, the system has no idea which color you like. In other words, the 'probability of liking' is spread thin equally for all colors. This is like the entire color space being covered in a 'fog of possibility'.
LogicAlgorithm.sec2Body2: Here, the magic of probability called 'Bayesian Inference' appears. When you answer 'I like color A', the system calculates 'Checks are high that colors close to A are liked' and 'Checks are high that colors close to B are disliked', and updates the density of the fog (update of posterior probability).
LogicAlgorithm.sec2Body3: Repeating this, the fog that was pure white at first gradually clears, and only one point begins to shine strongly. This is the process of identifying your preference. By taking the approach of 'narrowing down possibilities' rather than 'choosing the correct answer', identification with a small number of questions is made possible.
LogicAlgorithm.chartDesc1:
Since we don't know where the correct answer is at first,
the probability of all points is the same (uniform distribution).
LogicAlgorithm.chartDesc2:
As questions are repeated, only the probability density
of a specific area (preferred color) increases,
and others disappear.
LogicAlgorithm.sec3Body1: The system does not choose 2 colors properly every time. From thousands of combinations, it calculates and asks the 'Question that yields the most information (High Information Gain)'.
LogicAlgorithm.sec3Body2: For example, suppose you are asked 'Which do you like, Red or Blue?' and you answer 'Red'. If the system predicted 'You probably like Red' from the beginning, almost no new information is obtained from this question. Conversely, when 'two colors that are completely unpredictable 50-50' are presented, great value (amount of information) is born in your choice.
LogicAlgorithm.sec3Body3: In technical terms, the system avoids 'Questions that maximize entropy (uncertainty)' and looks for 'Questions that reduce entropy the most'. If a question comes up where you hesitate like 'I like both...' or 'Both are subtle...', that is proof that the algorithm is approaching your core. That 'hesitation' decision dramatically advances the diagnosis.

Harmonies.title: COLOR SCHEMES
Harmonies.subtitle: Color Scheme Gallery
Harmonies.defaultDesc: Visualizing the positional relationship of each color on the OKLCH hue circle. Geometric balance is the basis of beautiful color schemes.

complementary.name: Complementary
complementary.desc: Two colors located opposite each other on the color wheel. They create 'complementary contrast' that enhances each other most strongly. The visual impact is very strong, creating a dynamic and powerful energy.

analogous.name: Analogous
analogous.desc: A combination of colors adjacent to each other on the color wheel. Because they share common hue components, they harmonize extremely easily and are often found in nature. It is a color scheme that is calm, unified, and gives a sense of security.

rectangular.name: Rectangular
rectangular.desc: A composition of 4 colors including 2 sets of complementary pairs. This arrangement drawing a rectangle has a strong contrast of complementary colors while creating a rich resonance due to hue variations. A complex and sophisticated balance can be constructed.

analogousComplementary.name: Analogous Complementary
analogousComplementary.desc: A composition that adds a complement (opposite color) as an accent within the harmony of analogous colors. The 'unity' of analogous colors and the 'tension' of complementary colors coexist, creating a cohesive impression while avoiding boredom.

triadic.name: Triadic
triadic.desc: A color scheme of an equilateral triangle dividing the color wheel into three. Although the three colors have different personalities, geometric balance is maintained. It is a traditional color scheme that gives a lively and vibrant impression while having stability despite contrast.

splitComplementary.name: Split Complementary
splitComplementary.desc: A three-color composition (isosceles triangle) adopting two colors located on both sides of the complement. It softens the tension while maintaining the strong contrast of complementary colors. It has a good balance of contrast and harmony, and gives a sophisticated impression that is easy to handle.

tetradic.name: Tetradic
tetradic.desc: A color scheme of a square dividing the color wheel into four. Since four colors are at equal distances, it is particularly colorful and rhythmical among multi-color schemes. Since it includes two sets of complementary relationships, very rich and playful expressions are possible.

pentadic.name: Pentadic
pentadic.desc: A color scheme of a regular pentagon dividing the color wheel into five. Five colors are arranged like drawing a star. Because there are many colors, it is very gorgeous and has diversity like a kaleidoscope. By making one color the protagonist, order is born in the liveliness.

hexadic.name: Hexadic
hexadic.desc: A color scheme of a regular hexagon dividing the color wheel into six. Also called 'double triadic', it is a configuration where two equilateral triangles overlap. It has a rich spread of colors, and all colors resonate with each other, telling the pinnacle of harmony and diversity.
